comments.commentBody:
This was an unbelievably poor decision on Obama's part. Our nation is already embroiled in two wars which are projected to cost us, the people of America, $4 trillion. Our federal deficit is huge and even if rolled back to a $500 billion deficit per year, it does not take much figuring to understand that these deficits are unsustainable.

China is the largest holder and buyer of U.S. debt by a foreign country. Committing this small number of troops to Australia only serves to provoke China, in a time when mutual cooperation is the best course for both countries. Why is that empires, if we ever were one, are so compulsively ignorant to the very end. To invite more trouble and to be fractious in these times truly makes me doubt this president's intelligence and common sense, both of which are not evident in this short sighted decision.

I've been thinking for some time that for the Occupy movement to grow, it has to spread to universities, much like the Vietnam era protests. In those days, students occupied administration buildings, but it was not called an "Occupy..." movement. Universities are supposed to be places where free speech is encouraged, and young people are the future of the country. The Occupy movement is the strongest push for social change since the protests of the 1960s, which will scare both political parties (the Dems were the object and lost a Presidency in 1968, in spite of Lyndon Johnson's achievements in advancing civil rights). Unfortunately, this kind of activity can lead to over-reactions and violence. I hope that this time the level of violence will not reach that of the 1960s, when politically motivated violence was embodied in several assasinations, riots on campuses and in cities like Detroit, and deadly shootings at universities like Kent State. With the current climate in Washington, I wouldn't be surprised to see an escalation in violence from shear frustration at the government's inability to govern. Sad, but not surprised.
Time continues to run backwards -- soon only the rich will be able to attend college, just as it was 100 years ago.

@ #448: regarding UC-Davis, it's not that I think that UC Davis wouldn't let the protestors have a permit - it's that they *didn't.* Let's be clear, none of us would even be talking about Occupy UCD if they had ignored the relatively small group of tents in an open space on campus. Why provoke something if it's such an open and inviting free-speech loving campus? I'm from the East Coast and went to Duke & camped in a much larger tent-ville for basketball tickets, so the "tent camps are unsafe and dangerous" argument doesn't so much fly with me. I've been there, they aren't.

And anyway, the civil rights' movement was full of sit-ins, which are not marches and those people did not request permits. So if you're going to say what the Civil Rights' Movement did was ok, then you have to say what students are doing at UCD is ok. You can't condemn those students without condemning all the other movements in American history that camped. And anyway, some movements in American history were even violent - take the Boston Tea Party for instances. And I don't think you're (or anyone else on this site - even those that say the students deserved it!) would say anything bad about the Boston Tea Party.

So, after ordering Law Enforcement to do their jobs she throws them under the bus. Typical liberal hypocrite.
Papper Spray is the least force that they could have possibly used to gain compliance to the order that was in fact instigated by the actions and statements of the Administration.

Why should the cops be thrown under the bus for executing their SOP regardless of how poorit looks on TV.

What choice did they have as public servants? Go home and be fired?

Breaking News: UC Davis Officer Reinstated
http://www.thegopnet.com/breaking-news-uc-davis-officer-reinstated-70953

he does this with the relish of a true sadist.
sack him , or forever lose respect.

Did this surprise anyone?
The Republicans really thought they could (like they have done in the past) scream and stomp and hold their breaths until they got their own way. It was doomed from the start.
Now the question is how will the republicans hold up and be reasonable in the entire Congress. I suspect that the will try and do the same in public. Expect plenty of press conferences saying "he said, they said" Stay turned for the NRA and other right wing types to start the mantra the world's going to end.

It's too bad that the members of the panel can't be fired and barred from running for Congress again, since they have failed the American people, and it's clear that they are incompetent losers who can't do their jobs.

It's obvious that the Congress refuses to do anything that affects
the 1% of our country that can most help our democratic society out of it's deficit problem. When some of the wayout kids come after them with pitchforks the the Tea Party crowd won't them, they will too busy running for the hills.Neither will I.

Those who think the spraying was done out of meanness do not understand the pressures and limits put on Law Enforcement when they are told to remove law breakers who resist them (yes passive resistance is still resistance). They are duty sworn to uphold their oath, and they are duty bound to answer complaints.
Pepper Spray is the end result and it is the LEAST force that can be effectively deployed in this situation to gain complaince from those resisting a legal order.
Although I agree it looks sloppy and uncomfortable in a short clip, this officer was in fact following his SOP and orders and was in fact using minimum force. And on top of that he had no other avenue or tool at his disposal which was better than the one he used.
Thinking this was sadistic is understandable, but ignorant and incorrect all the same.

Romney has two advantages in making a play for Iowa:
1: He can still push low expectations via a "I started late" explanation; or a "compared to 4 years ago I spent 1/2 the money but I got x,000 more votes"; and
2: Perry and Gringrich may split the tea party vote. Grinrich has the better press / polls (currently); while Perry has the better organisation (matters in caucus states - just ask BHO). Plus Ron Paul will takes his 10% cut.
While the results will be important; I think the spin is going to be as important for later races (BHO's "yes we can" speech post his NH loss set him up for some later results).

Jimeny cricket, what about the famiies who are unable to produce on a specific timetable?  What is, is.  My kids are 5 1/2 yrs apart, that's simply the way the universe decided it should be.  Children are flexible, resiliant, and react to their environment.

there's so much to do,never figure out even one method benefit the public
vansshoe

It is an old saying but true as ever. When the only tool in your toolbox is a hammer, all problems look like nails. So here comes China looking like a nail that needs hammering. What is so embarrassing about this military response is that we so readily admit we cannot compete commercially. We can not compete politically. We can not compete on our character. We send in the Marines. God help America.
Carl, Portland

So is it the end of the beginning or the beginning of the end.  We must see the separation of religion and state in any new government.  Freedom will be lost if the religious extremists gain control as is the case in Iran.  Young Egyptians must see the light and keep the separation of God and government.  You must figure as to why.....

America has clearly&wisely abandoning its unipolar status voluntarily opted to multipolar status atleast as far as facing,balancing&neutralising the hegemonic behavior of the upcoming superpower starved CHINA.Also in this fine pivotal act of single sweep President OBAMA has brought lot closer few of the like minded democracies together in that region like australia,india,indonesia&japan.This speaks volume for his foreign policy savyness as opposed to the intellectually challenged republican candidates like CAIN&PERRY.

The article overlooked the fact that many Sunni treat Shia like second class citizens in Bahrain and there is obvious discrimination.  It's a strange place where Sunni are fed stories of the terrifying Shia but the only ones with weapons are Sunni.  No investigation results will change this.  It's up to the government to do the right thing and, unfortunately, they're the ones doing the wrong thing in almost all cases.

Symbolic armies are nothing. I understand our concern to voicing our interest in the region against Chinese interests; however, they have a military budget around 65 billion dollars a year, while we spend much more. Even if we spent proportionally the same amount as China, our spending would be much less a percentage of our GDP than it is. If we really need this immense military force everwhere, then we ought to raise revenues to pay for it.
This argument sounds reasonable if we do indeed transfer forces instead of increasing them.
It is really pretty obvious is it not. Of course we need to spend more money.
In order for Australia to become an ally to the USA should Australia have a military base in the USA?  If not, why not?

I see Mr Cheng's ideas on the topic simply representing GOP business interests and a means of providing public money for the ever-hungry M-I complex. This constant need to expand the military , to create new weapons systems based on imaginary bogeymen. This is the beginning of sabre-rattling and does not serve the free world-or even the Communist Chinese world-- well. It is an artificial paranoia and a preparation of the minds and hearts of American citizens that the day may come when we need to do battle with China. China is an old civilization and they have had their wars of conquest and unification. do they really hunger for another battle? I doubt it.
Anyone with just the basics of history will see that Western Europeans/Americans have had their years of trying to conquer the nations surrounding them and even further away. Why all of a sudden are we so concerned if China wants to try it's hand. Many have tried--not one has succeeded. Aren't we better off trying to live at peace with each other? Haven't the militaries of the world killed off enough people--mostly innocent? One has to hope that the Chinese people themselves are not interested in conquest--it is largely a "government" idea, that rarely represents the thought of the people. I'm too busy trying to survive and have no interest is taking over another nation, by force or otherwise.

As usual, Nye makes excellent and compelling observations on international relations. There are, however, three key issues regarding this "pivot" toward Asia/Pacific. First, just because the U.S. now realizes that we "wasted" our time in the Middle East and Central Asia, and we want to pivot away from it, there is no guarantee that the situation will allow us to do that. With new developments in Iran, Syria, and Egypt, all signs point to more complications and intractable problems that will require more attention and resources. Second, U.S. would be better served by thinking more strategically about what message it wants to send to China, and how this message will be interpreted by the China government, the governments in Taipei, Hanoi, Tokyo, Jakarta, and Manila. Stationing Marines in Darwin and strutting about it could very easily result in unpredictable outcomes that can grow out of control. Smaller countries can be emboldened to provoke China, Tokyo might ask U.S. to reduce U.S. forces in Japan, radical Islamists could step up attracts in Philippines and Indonesia to stoke anti-American sentiments with China's tacit if passive approval. Certainly, the racial optics are all wrong--U.S. and Australia, two white settler nations protecting their interests in Asia and the Pacific. Finally, just as Chinese government is changing leadership and the growing middle class is making ever greater demands for reform, this announcement gave the Chinese Communist Party a HUGE gift. The CCP and the People's Liberation Army will use this to rally Chinese citizens that, indeed, the Western world and their sycophants in East Asia will not stand for a strong and independent China.

Better approach would have been For the U.S. to take diplomatic leadership and bring China as one of many co-equals to work on maritime security, territorial disputes, and economic cooperation. More than territory (China has more than enough), China and Chinese want respect and constructive engagement.

If we look for war, we will find it. If we look instead for peaceful solutions, they too will be at hand. 60 million dead in WWII should be enough to convince anyone that war is futile. We have lost so much potential that it is no possible to calculate it. How many great people have died in vain? How much culture  been lost? When I was a young student researching in musicology, I got many replies to inquires from German archives and libraries--sorry, Kriegs verlust!--war loss! let's save the people and our cultural treasures--try diplomacy more, bark less.
